title: Godel Iceport
text:
Godel Iceport is an <a href="iceport">iceport</a> about wide, which marks a more-or-less permanent indentation in the seaward front of the extensive <a href="ice%20shelf">ice shelf</a> fringing the coast of <a href="Queen%20Maud%20Land">Queen Maud Land</a>.
Discovery and naming.
Godel Iceport was named by <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> <a href="Operation%20Deep%20Freeze">Operation Deep Freeze I</a> personnel on the <a href="USS%20Glacier%20%28AGB-4%29">USS "Glacier" (AGB-4)</a>, who made a <a href="running%20survey">running survey</a> of this coast in March 1956, for <a href="William%20H.%20Godel">William H. Godel</a>, deputy director of the Office of Special Operations, <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20the%20Navy">Department of the Navy</a>, who assisted in formulating expedition plans and policy.
The term "iceport" was suggested by the <a href="Advisory%20Committee%20on%20Antarctic%20Names">Advisory Committee on Antarctic Names</a> in 1956 to denote an ice shelf indentation, subject to configuration changes, which may offer <a href="anchor">anchor</a>age or possible access to the upper surface of an ice shelf via ice ramps along one or more sides of the feature.
